description.narrative: Programme quality and learning is incomplete without reference to knowledge management that is defined by key tenets of data generation, data/information processing and storage and information use in learning and improvement. Hence, programme quality ispremised on a well conceptualised and designed programme that is itself anchored on the existing context and needs of affected target beneficiaries. In order to generate credible data to design quality programmes, there is need to invest in studies and data systems to capture, store, process/analyse and retrieve data for use, as well as enhance technical capacity of data/information users. Currently, with over 40 projects being implemented by Oxfam in Uganda and its partners, there is a great amount of data generated on a daily basis. Most of the data is compartmentalised and/or managed only at the project level and not necessarily aligned to the thematic areasthat are relate to the OCS strategic objectives. Data is updated just only in time for reporting; and there are virtually no data quality checks in place. This compromises data reliability and credibility. In a nutshell, there is no central repository that will guarantee institutional memory and future reference. The prevailing state of data management makes it difficult to process data and present a country level performance, and/or readily inform annual or global reporting. Programmatic information is piecemeal and doesnot fully represent the breadth or impact of Oxfam’s work. The existing platforms (Box, Atlas and Adobe/SAP) are good for information filing and profiling. These shortfalls limit getting the needed value from the data generated in the organisation. They compromise access to real time data, data processing, data collation, data analysis, data retrieval and report generation from any location.Continuing with the current data management practices will make it impossible to realise a robust MEAL system envisioned in the draft OCS (2020-2030); and does not resonate with Oxfam as aknowledge leader. Further, mutual learning and accountability to stakeholders will not be effective without a robust database.

participating-org.narrative: Oxfam Novib is one of the 17 national affiliates of the Oxfam International Confederation. It started life in 1956 as the Netherlands Organisation for International Assistance (Novib), and joined forces with Oxfam in 1994. Working together in confederation, the Oxfam affiliates can speak with one clear and compelling voice on issues of global concern: climate change, health and education forall, agriculture, trade, and conflicts and emergencies. Oxfam established this country office to support local organizations and projects. Through this local office Oxfam Novib directly contributes towards this project’s implementation.

mailing-address.narrative: PO box 30919, 2500 GX The Hague, The Netherlands

sector.narrative: The right to social and political participation
